As I remember: one SpaceX booster: 50+ Million USD. Fuel for said booster: 0.2 Million USD. A difference of "only" 250 times. Even when you have to check and re-check the engines; SpaceX should easily be able to underbid the next cheapest supplier by 50% once the reflying boosters thing is going full swing and becomes the norm.
Which might cause a shutdown --- or at least an attempt of a shutdown --- from the "establishment" (see OTRAG) or them getting on their behinds and instead of merely copying SpaceX they might seriously think about other launch systems, like a Lofstrom Loop.

Dude you missed out the most obvious one Voyager 1 a  testament to the robustness of Voyager 1, the Voyager team completed a successful test of the spacecraft's "trajectory correction maneuver" (TCM) thrusters on November 28, 2017. The last time these backup thrusters were fired up was in November of 1980, 37 years prior. Voyager project manager Suzanne Dodd anticipates that successful utilization of the TCM thrusters will extend the Voyager mission by an additional "two to three years" now that takes the prize 37 years after the fact.

I, personally, cannot WAIT until the day SpaceX casually lobs a tesla to mars orbit. Having so much power available and reusable (Aside from the upper stage, but that's another story) will really start to make an impact on access to space. If you just pay for the upper stage, maintenance and fuel rather than the entire assembly, it will be so much cheaper to go so much further than ever imagined. Then BFR comes along and makes the whole works reusable so you only pay for fuel and maintenance, just like an aircraft.

We are making a second golden age right now. Let's not waste it like we did the last one!

The one complaint I have about "reusability will make it cheap!" is that it hasn't. The Space Shuttle reused the most expensive parts, yet was more expensive than Apollo for launching people. (I'm not even going to get in to launching satellites, because the Space Shuttle really wasn't good at that - it had to carry the complexity of a man-rated vehicle even when it was only launching satellites.) The Shuttle was great - but cost effective it was not. SpaceX Falcon 9, in reused/reusable configuration is the cheapest launch vehicle - but it's not the reusability; for a given payload, a throwaway Falcon 9 is cheaper than a reusable Falcon Heavy, per SpaceX price lists. So obviously reusability doesn't make it even 3x cheaper, much less 10x or more. (Since if reusability were 3x cheaper, Falcon Heavy reusable would be the same price as Falcon 9 throwaway.)

I don't doubt that in the very long term, reusability will end up being cheaper - and that improvements in rocket technology will allow it to be even cheaper still; but as yet, reusability is not making spaceflight orders-of-magnitude cheaper as has been promised for decades.

Last quibble - the fact that SpaceX makes things "in house" does not inherently make them cheaper. Their improvements in manufacturing have. Most manufacturing industries don't make every single part in house. They realize that for many things, sourcing parts from a company that specializes in that type of part is cheaper than making the part on their own. The "in house" isn't the cost savings, it's the design and manufacturing. They could just as easily have sourced the same parts from external companies with contracts specifying a certain price per part - and there are many companies that would be able to provide at similar cost - possibly cheaper if they are also allowed to sell those same parts to other companies.
